title: Baking Terms Quiz
description: Do you know your baking vocabulary? From 'proof' to 'fold,' test your knowledge!

questions.question: In baking, what does 'proofing' refer to?
options: Checking if a cake is done

questions.question: What does it mean to 'cream' butter and sugar together?
options: Beat them until light and fluffy

questions.question: What is a 'bain-marie' (water bath) used for in baking?
options: Gentle, even heating to prevent cracking or curdling

questions.question: What does 'folding' mean in a baking recipe?
options: Gently combining a light mixture into a heavier one without deflating

questions.question: What is 'blind baking'?
options: Pre-baking a pie crust without the filling

questions.question: What does 'docking' dough mean?
options: Letting it rest on a counter
Poking holes in it to prevent puffing during baking
Joining two pieces of dough together

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'tempering' eggs in baking?
options: Beating them until stiff peaks form
Separating the yolks from the whites
Gradually warming them to prevent scrambling when added to a hot mixture

questions.question: In baking, what does 'leavening' do?
options: Causes dough or batter to rise

questions.question: What does the term 'crumb' refer to when describing a baked item?
options: The internal texture and structure of the bread or cake
The leftover pieces on the plate

questions.question: What is a 'couche' used for in bread baking?
options: A linen cloth that supports dough while it proofs

questions.question: What does 'scoring' bread dough before baking accomplish?
options: Controls where the bread expands and allows steam to escape

questions.question: What is an 'autolyse' in bread making?
options: A rest period after mixing flour and water, before adding other ingredients

questions.question: What does it mean when a recipe says to bake until a toothpick comes out 'clean'?
options: No wet batter clings to a toothpick inserted in the center
The edges have pulled away from the pan

questions.question: What is a 'roux' in the context of baking and cooking?
options: A mixture of fat and flour used to thicken sauces

questions.question: What does 'laminating' dough mean, as done when making croissants?
options: Repeatedly folding butter into dough to create thin, flaky layers
